Hey,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> I'm afra=
id that after discussion, we're still reluctant to have JUnit 
> natively f=
ilter stack traces.  It looks to me that this is something 
> that could wo=
rk in a custom runner--are you interested in seeing if
this 
> is so?

Mayb=
e. My time is pretty limited in the coming weeks though. One thing
to think=
 about: maybe it'd make sense to have a filteredTrace property
on the resul=
t object (I'm not sure how this actually works, would we
need to clone exce=
ptions).

What use cases are you thinking of for unfiltered stack traces? A=
re
these cases so common that a system property to toggle the filtering
wou=
ldn't meet everyone's needs?

The fact that both ant and eclipse (the two m=
ain frontends to junit)
filter stack traces *by default* seems to be a sign=
 that the primary
user base wants filtering. However, the filters used toda=
y actually
lose *real* data because they filter out things like sun's refle=
ction
technology, which might be important for a test case that used reflec=
tion.
 
> Also, thank you for all of your feedback so far, and please do ke=
ep 
> considering ways we can improve the framework.  The sourceforge proje=
ct 
> page has a convenient place for any future patches.  Thanks,

Ok, tha=
nks. I wasn't quite sure what the best place was.

-- Ben
